items.title: India's Medical Devices Sector: PLI Progress & 2026 Outlook
items.summary:
- PLI drives execution: 2025 market US$14–16B, projected US$30–50B by 2030; INR 34.2B outlay; 22 greenfield projects; 55+ devices produced; exports ₹58.69B.
- 2026 shifts to complex manufacturing; clusters/parks mature; standalone Medical Device Rules 2017; India as a China-plus-one diversification node; rising imports in high-tech segments.
- Outlook: 2026–2030 consolidation with export credentials, R&D/MSME integration; opportunities in components, contract manufacturing, regulatory/QA; risks include post-PLI sustainability and regulatory delays.

items.title: What is India’s FDI Outlook for 2026? Key Policy Changes, Sectors, and Trade Deals
items.summary:
- India’s 2026 FDI outlook centers on services-led scale, digitally enabled consumption, and export-oriented manufacturing aided by new FTAs and policy reforms.
- Key reforms include insurance liberalization to 100% FDI, treaty reform, FOCE framework, SWAGAT-FI onboarding, and retrospective validation of bonus shares, boosting investor certainty.
- Watch sectors: IT/services, electronics, auto components, agri-food, life sciences, renewables; new trade deals with UK/EU expand tariffs, data flows, and investment opportunities.

items.title: Managing AI Slop: Why Due Diligence is Essential for Businesses Using Generative AI
items.author: India Briefing
items.summary:
- AI slop: highly plausible but false outputs that evade detection; verification and governance essential beyond traditional QA.
- Five principles: purpose-bound use; line-by-line verification of facts and citations; traceable AI usage; transparent client disclosures; training to raise AI literacy and recognize failure modes.
- Industry risk profiles and governance: high risk for professional services; medium-high for tech; very high for research; include board questions, vendor due diligence, and audit trails.

items.title: Merchant Shipping Act, 2025: Insights for Trade & Logistics Businesses
items.summary: - Modernises India’s maritime law by aligning with SOLAS, MARPOL, STCW and MLC 2006; consolidates into 16 parts and 325 sections; expands ownership eligibility (NRIs, OCIs, LLPs) and permits bareboat-charter with eventual ownership transfer; expands the Tonnes Tax Scheme and enables fully digital, simplified registration for both sea and inland vessels.\n- Introduces a regime for abandoned crews, strengthens enforcement and emergency response; expands DGMA powers and cross-agency coordination; mandates disclosure of all shipping charges and digital filings; supports a risk-based digital inspection system with centralized data access.\n- Extends coverage to all sea-going vessels, adds new registration categories (permanent, provisional, temporary, bareboat-charter); liberalizes ownership; tightens labor/certification/training obligations; clarifies liability and mandatory insurance for pollution and wreck removal with direct rights against insurers and P&I schemes.

items.title:
Goa: Investment Outlook amid Tourism Revival, Sector Diversification
December 10, 2025 by India Briefing

Goa’s 2025 investment landscape reflects steady diversification beyond tourism, with new project approvals and major PPP-led infrastructure commitments. For investors, the state offers expanding opportunities across tourism-linked services and niche industrial segments.
India Opens PLI Applications for Bulk Drug Manufacturing till December 26, 2025
items.summary:
- Sixth round of Bulk Drug PLI opens; online applications invited Nov 27–Dec 26, 2025, focusing on Meropenem (min 4 MT/yr; total 16 MT; up to 4 applicants) and Ritonavir (min 5 MT/yr; total 20 MT; up to 4 applicants). 
- Applications via plibulkdrugs.ifciltd.com; guidelines at pharma-dept.gov.in; earlier May 2025 added 11 categories; India imports ~70% of bulk drugs; as of Aug 2025, 32 greenfield firms selected and 48 projects approved across 33 APIs/KSMs/Dis. 
- Aim to cut import dependence and boost domestic capacity; Bulk Drug Parks and PLI schemes to strengthen supply chains through FY2029-30.

India Expands Electronics Manufacturing Push with Second ECMS Approval Round
items.summary: - 17 ECMS projects worth INR 71.72 bn (US$808 mn) across 9 states; target output INR 651.11 bn and 11,808 direct jobs.\n- Shifts to component/sub-system manufacturing (phones, IT, wearables, telecom, EV, defence, medical, renewables); ARKA-GKT1 edge chip by Cyient Semiconductors & Azimuth AI.\n- Launched Apr 8, 2025 with a six-year tenure; first tranche had 7 projects; aims for a self-reliant, globally competitive electronics components ecosystem.
